entry.p: Riffing on a post by Arnold Kling, who in turn was riffing on Marc Andreessen, I've been pondering the topics that various schools of thought tend to ignore. Kling was talking about politics: conservatives don't like to discuss beneficial social changes they once opposed, progressives don't like to consider anything but oppression as a cause of disparate outcomes, etc. However, we can apply the same line of thinking to philosophies. Here are a few possibilities:

ul.li: Aristotelians give short shrift to moral rules and behavioral policies.
Kantians give short shrift to character traits and the outcomes of action.
Utilitarians give short shrift to personal relationships and character traits.
Stoics give short shrift to emotions and the irreplaceable value of loved ones.
Epicureans give short shrift to the socio-political environment in which one lives.
Confucians give short shrift to spontaneity and living in the moment.
Taoists give short shrift to deliberation and planning for the future.

entry.p: And so on. It'd be a worthwhile exercise to think this through more fully.
